concern:
Hey guys, recently turned 22 am currently a junior in university . I am currently unemployed and haven't had a job only had 2 jobs in my life and had done doordash sometimes. I recently started working out and have been doing more house chores and helping my mom with the house. Picking up my siblings and dropping them off at school. I live at home which I am thankful. So I maintain the house like mopping and washing dishes. Doing errands. 

 I hang out with my gf almost everyday and play video games for a couple hours. I was wondering how I could be more productive and feel useful. I feel like im a mooch or a no life without a part time job. Me and my gf go out a lot and explore new areas. I feel like my family thinks im lazy. Even though I know im just finishing this semester and still got one year left for my bachelors.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello, and welcome. How are you feeling today? Is there anything on your mind that youd like to talk about?
I'm feeling a bit anxious about my daily life and productivity lately. Yes, I'd like to talk about ways to feel more useful and less like I'm not contributing enough.

That sounds like a really important topic for you. It's understandable that you might feel anxious about your daily life and productivity. Can you tell me more about what's been contributing to these feelings of anxiety?

I've been feeling anxious mainly because my daily routine doesn't feel productive enough, even though I'm managing school and home responsibilities. It's hard not to worry about contributing more when I compare myself to others who are working or more independent.

It sounds like you're putting a lot of pressure on yourself to be more productive and independent, especially when you compare yourself to others. It's important to remember that everyone has their own unique path and timeline, and it's okay to focus on your own journey. Have you considered setting small, achievable goals for yourself to help you feel more productive and useful?

I've thought about setting small goals, like organizing my daily schedule better, but I'm not sure where to start. It could help me feel more productive and less anxious about my contributions at home and school.

It's great that you're open to setting small goals to help you feel more productive. Here's a suggestion try breaking down your daily schedule into smaller, manageable tasks and prioritize them based on importance. This can help you stay organized and focused on one task at a time. What do you think about starting with something like creating a to-do list for tomorrow?

I think creating a to-do list for tomorrow sounds like a practical first step to make my day feel more structured. It could help me build that sense of productivity and reduce my anxiety about not contributing enough right now.

Great! When creating your to-do list for tomorrow, consider including a mix of tasks related to your responsibilities at home and school. This can help you balance your contributions in both areas. Which tasks do you think you'll prioritize for tomorrow's list?

I think I'll prioritize tasks like helping with house chores in the morning and reviewing my school assignments in the afternoon to balance my responsibilities. This should help me feel more productive and useful throughout the day.

It's wonderful to see your commitment to setting small, achievable goals. Creating a to-do list with a mix of tasks related to your responsibilities at home and school is an excellent first step. Prioritizing house chores in the morning and reviewing school assignments in the afternoon can help you maintain balance and feel more productive. Remember to take things one step at a time, and be kind to yourself as you work towards your goals. Keep up the great work, and I look forward to our next contact in a month to discuss your progress!

Thanks for the encouragement I'll focus on my to-do list to balance home and school tasks and start feeling more useful in my daily routine. I look forward to updating you next month on how it's going.
